name: Propanamide, N-2-benzothiazolyl-3,3,3-trifluoro-2-(trifluoromethyl)-
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-4009

name: Propanamide, N-2-benzothiazolyl-3,3,3-trifluoro-2-(trifluoromethyl)-
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-4009
Reason: The compound N-2-benzothiazolyl-3,3,3-trifluoro-2-(trifluoromethyl)propanamide is relatively complex and consists of several different functional groups that affect the melting point in various ways. We'll analyze the effects of these groups based on a basic propanamide structure. Propanamide itself has a melting point around 81-84°C. Firstly, the benzothiazolyl group, a heteroaromatic system, provides significant rigidity to the molecule and increases the potential for π-π stacking interactions, typically adding around 40-60°C to the melting point of a compound. Secondly, each trifluoromethyl (-CF3) group, due to its electronegativity and bulkiness, tends to increase the melting point significantly, often by about 20-30°C per group. Considering there are two such groups, this could add approximately 40-60°C. Lastly, we must consider the influence of the amide group. The amide linkage typically contributes to the melting point due to strong hydrogen bonding; however, since the basic propanamide already accounts for this effect, it will not be included in the additive effects. Adding these contributions together, we predict an increase of about 80-120°C on top of the base value of propanamide.
